text:
The Golden Globes marks the start of the 2018 awards season. But this year, many female celebrities are eschewing the typical brightly colored dresses and statement-making patterns on the red carpet for something more powerful—all black.

The call to wear black comes from the ambitious Time’s Up initiative, created by 300 actresses and female agents, writers, directors, and executives, including such power players as Eva Longoria , Shonda Rimes , and Reese Witherspoon . The goal of Time’s Up is to combat inequality, sexual harassment, and sexual assault in the workplace; the movement already has a $14 million legal defense fund. Time’s Up is a direct response to the #MeToo movement that has upended industries from politics to Hollywood to restaurants to journalism by exposing sexual harassment and sexual assault in the workplace—and actually, miraculously, holding abusers accountable.

The all-black fashion statement could be classified as a silent protest, but the purpose is loud and clear: It’s a powerful show of support for the many people who are speaking out against their powerful abusers. Longoria told The New York Times , “This is a moment of solidarity, not a fashion moment. For years, we’ve sold these awards shows as women, with our gowns and colors and our beautiful faces and our glamour. This time the industry can’t expect us to go up and twirl around. That’s not what this moment is about.”

See below for a growing list of the actresses who participated in the red carpet blackout at the Golden Globes.
title: Golden Globes 2018: Black Dresses, Time’s Up, and Fashion as Activism
